Name: p-Nitrochlorobenzene
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.57 (2005)): The substance causes mild irritation, if any, to the eyes.

Name: p-Nnitrophenol
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (CERI Hazard Data 2001-65 (2002) and ATSDR (1992)): "Iris congestion, lens opacity, puruloid effusion," "moderate to severe corneal opacity, bullous tissues of the conjunctiva and neovascularization in the cornea" indicative of corrosivity.

Name: Terephthalic Acid
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (CERI Hazard Data 97-23 (1998), ACGIH (7th, 2001) and SIDS (2004)): "non-irritating" or "slightly irritating." The substance is thus considered a "mild irritant."

Name: Ethanol, 2-(diethylamino)-
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: Since there is the conclusion data of "critical damage over an eye" (CERI Hazard Data (2001)) and it was set to Category 1C on the skin, it was set as Category 1.

Name: 4-Vinyl-1-cyclohexene
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: Based on a report on rabbit eye irritation test results (ACGIH (7th, 2001)): "focal corneal necrosis was observed."

Name: Ethylbenzene
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of rabbit eye irritation tests (EHC 186 (1996)) "mild irritation to the conjunctiva, and no or reversible effects, if any, on the cornea." The substance is thus considered slightly or mildly irritating to the eye.

Name: Styrene
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on human epidemiological studies and rabbit eye irritation tests (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.52 (2004): "moderate irritation (for seven days)."

Name: Benzyl chloride
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: Based on the description of the human health effects (MOE Risk Assessment vol. 4 (2005)): "The substance is corrosive to the eye. In the form of vapour, it causes irritation of the eye, skin and respiratory tract."

Name: Benzonitrile
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A-2B
Rationale for classification: Since stimulus condition like the redness of a conjunctiva and conjunctiva dropsy is acknowledged as a result of the injections against eyes of rabbit (IUCLID (2000)), and there is the description that a human ocular is stimulated (ICSC (J), (1999), SITTIG (4th, 2002), and HSFS (2000)), it is set as Category 2A-2B. In addition, the detailed categorization from the acquired information is difficult.

Name: Benzaldehyde
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (DFGOT Vol.17 (2002)): "slightly irritative."

Name: N-Methylaniline
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A-2B
Rationale for classification: Based on human epidemiological findings (CERI Hazard Data 2001-2 (2002)): "The substance, in the form of vapour or mist, has a potential for irritation of the eyes, mucous membrane and upper respiratory tract." Also based on the evidence of "reddening and pain" (ICSC (1994)). Although classified into Category 2A-2B because the severity of irritation is unknown, the substance should be placed in Category 2A from the viewpoint of safety, if further subclassification is needed.

Name: phenyl hydrazine
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: We classified it as Category 2A based on the description that serious purulent conjunctivitis was acknowledged in the test applied to the eyes of the rabbits (CICAD 19 (2000)).

Name: 2-Vinylpyridine
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on eye irritation tests in rabbits and guinea pigs (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.18 (2005) and PATTY (4th, 2000)): "severely irritating."

Name: Morpholine, 4-ethyl-
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: From statements that although a corneal edema was acknowledged in 40ppm, it recovered in several hours, and that although the stimulation was felt for the ophthalmic in 50-100ppm, the stimulation in 50ppm was small in humans (ACGIH (2001)), it was taken as Category 2B.

Name: 1,3,5,7-Tetraazatricyclo[3.3.1.13.7]decane; Hexamethylenetetramine
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the description of the human health effects (MOE Risk Assessment vol. 4 (2004) and DFGOT vol.5 (1993)): "The substance slightly irritates the eye," though the results of rabbit eye irritation tests suggest no irritation (DFGOT vol.5 (1993)).

Name: Barium nitrate
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: The substance is classified into Category 2A as available eye irritation studies in rabbits provide no description of corrosivity, though they provide the evidence of "severe irritation."

Name: Cadmium nitrate, tetrahydrate
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: In accordance with the technical guideline, given the fact that the substance is classified into Category 1 of skin corrosion/irritation.

Name: Disulfur dichloride
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: It is described that when human eye was touched, "important ocular burn" would be caused, and its recovery took 14 months (IUCLID (2000)). Moreover, there are statements of "corrosive" and "a permanent deficit is caused."to a human eye (HSDB 2005). As mentioned above, it was judged that it had irreversible impacts and it was set as Category 1.

Name: Silane, trichloro-
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: In ICSC(J)(2002) and HSFS (1999), there is a statement that corrosion to the human eye is caused, and in HSDB (2002), there is a statement that thermal burn to the human eye is caused. So it was set as Category 1.

Name: Phosphoryl trichloride
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: This product is a skin corrosive substance. With a rabbit, there is a statement of strong eye stimulativeness and a strong necrosis, and loss of eyesight (IUCLID (2000), GESTIS (2005)), and with humans,  there is a statement of strong eye stimulativeness, corrosiveness, and loss of eyesight is (ACGIH (7th, 2001), ICSC (J), (2002), HSDB (2005)). So it was set as Category 1.

Name: Phosphorus pentachloride
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: It was categoried into Category 1 from skin corrosivity / irritation being categoried into Category 1B.

Name: ozone
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A-2B
Rationale for classification: Based on that eye irritation was seen in humans (PATTY (5th, 2001), it was set as Category 2A-2B.

Name: lead arsenite
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Due to the descriptions that it irritates to human eyes (ICSC, 1999; HSFS, 2001), and that inorganic arsenic dust shows eye irritation (HSG 70, 1992-IM 042, 1996), it was classified into Category 2B.

Name: hydrogen iodide
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: From the description that critical irritation is indicated to the human eye in Priority 1 (PATTY (5th, 2001)), and the document of Priority 2 had description "caustic is indicated to an eye" (ICSC (J) (1999), SITTIG (4th, 2002)), it was set as Category 1.

Name: Hydrobromic acid
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 1 based on the report (DFGOT vol.13 (1999)) of the serious eye membrane stimulus by humans (DFGOT vol.13 (1999)), and a statement called corrosiveness (ICSC (J), (2001)).

Name: Boric acid
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A-2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the description of the human health effects (ATSDR (1992) and ACGIH (7th, 2005)): The substance irritates the human eye (though the severity of the effects and recovery period are not presented). Although classified into Category 2A-2B, it should be placed in Category 2A from the viewpoint of safety if further subclassification is needed.

Name: mercury dinitrate
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: There is the descripiton of oculo corrosiveness (ICSC, 2000), and it is classified into Category 1 in description of skin corrosivenesses. So it was classified into Category 1.

Name: Chlorine dioxide
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: There is the description that in evidence of exposure in humans eye irritations were acknowldged (CICAD 37 (2002)), and the description that the eyes are stimulated seriously (ICSC (J)(1999)). So it was set as Category 2A.

Name: Lead dinitrate
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A-2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the description of acute effects on humans (ICSC (J) (1999)): "reddening and pain" were observed in the eye. The substance is thus considered to produce eye irritation of unknown degree. It should be placed in Category 2A from the viewpoint of safety is further subclassification is needed.

Name: 3,3'-Dichloro-4,4'-diaminodiphenylmethane
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of "mild irritation" from rabbit eye irritation tests (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.33, 2005).

Name: Diphenylmethane diisocyanate   (4,4'-M.D.I.)
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A-2B
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2A-2B from description that the eye of the rabbit is stimulated (IARC 19 (1979)).

Name: 4,4'-Methylenedianiline
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (SIDS (2002)): "The substance produced mild to moderate irritation of the eye."

Name: Diphenyl ether
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Since there was information of mild irritation in the data of HSDB (2005), it was set as Category 2B.

Name: m-bis(2,3-epoxypropoxy)benzene
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: We classified it as Category 2A based on the descriptions that severe irritational property was acknowledged when applied to the eyes of the rabbits (DFGOT (vol.7, 1996) and IARC 36 (1985)).

Name: sodium selenite
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: It is considered that there is strong stimulativeness to the eye in human from the description (redness, pain, damage, etc.) ( ACGIH-TLV (2004), ICSC (J), (1998), SITTIG (4th, 2002), and HSFS (2002)), and it was classified into Category 2A.

Name: nitrogen dioxide
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A-2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the description that the eyes are stimulated seriously (ICSC (J), (1997), and HSFS (2000)), it was set as Category 2A-2B.

Name: Thallium nitrate
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on epidemiological studies of human exposure (HSDB (2006)): "The substance severely burns the skin and eye." The substance is thus considered to have corrosive effects on the eye.

Name: arsenic acid, copper salt
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Since there are the descriptions that this product irritates to the eye, causes redness and pain (ICSC(J), 1993), it was classified into Category 2B.

Name: Dimercury dichloride
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A-2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in ICSC (J) (2000): "flare and irritation of the eye/skin/respiratory tract." The substance is thus considered to cause eye irritation (though the severity of the effects is not presented) and classified into Category 2A-2B from the viewpoint of safety.

Name: potassium arsonate
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: There is the descriptions that this product irritates to the eye (ICSC, 1999), may irritate (SITTIG 4th, 2002; HSFS, 1999), and the dust of this product or arsenic compound (dust) irritates to eyes (HSDB, 2002; HSG 70, 1992; PIM 042, 1996). So it was classified into Category 2B.

Name: 1,3-diphenylguanidine
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2
Rationale for classification: From the description that it is PII:20 (maximum: 110) in case of 20mg application and it recovers in 7days and it is PII:48 (maximum: 110) in case of 100 mg application and it recovers in 21 days in the eye irritation test (Draize Test) employing rabbits (SIDS (draft, 2002)), it was classified into Category 2. EU classification is Xi; R36 (EU-Annex I) and is equivalent to Category 2.

Name: ferrocene
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the statement of the eye irritations to humans, it was set as Category 2B.

Name: Triethanolamine
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: There is the description that in the eye irritation tests using the rabbit, irritation was asknowledged and it recovered completely 14 days afterward (ACGIH (7th, 2001), PATTY (4th, 1994), and NTP TR 518 (2004)). So it was set as Category 2A.

Name: 2-(Di-n-butylamino)ethanol
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on eye irritation tests (ACGIH (7th, 2001)): "DBAE caused corneal necrosis." The substance is thus considered to cause irreversible damage to the eye and classified into Category 1.

Name: Tributan-1-ylamine
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2
Rationale for classification: Although there is description that when Grade 1-10 estimates the irritation of amines in the eye irritation test employing rabbits, this substance shows "Grade 1: slight necrosis when 0.5 mLof non-diluted substance is instilled in the eye."(Patty (5th, 2001) effect), the level of irritation is unknown. Moreover, there is a description of "Almost all aliphatic Amins has eye irritation" (Patty (5th, 2001)), "It has serious influence and may cause dacryorrhea, conjunctivitis, and cornea dropsy," "It has irritation" (HSDB (2002)), and "It has a slight irritation."(ICSC (2005)). Although the level of irritation ranges from severe to mild, since this substance was a skin irritation substance, it was classified into Category 2.

Name: 2,2-Dibromo-2-cyanoacetamide
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: It has been described that "there is severe damage to a corneal, no recoverability, and it is corrosive" (HSDB (2002)) in the eye irritation test employing rabbits. Moreover, it has been described as "Severe" (RTECS (2008)) in the standard Draize test employing rabbits. As mentioned above, it was classified into Category 1.

Name: Methamidophos
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the data on rabbit eye irritation tests (IUCLID (2000)): "Mildly irritating."

Name: boron tribromide
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 1 based on statements that it is a skin corrosive substance,  there is caustic strong for eye in humans, and there is an example which bequeathed the scar strong against a cornea and a conjunctiva  (HSDB (2005)), and the statement that redness, a pain, and severe burns are produced in an eye (ICSC (J), (2001), HSDB (2005)).

Name: boron trichloride
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: There is the description which indicates the oculo corrosivenesses in human (ICSC (J), (1997), SITTIG (4th, 2002), and HSFS (2001)), and it was classified into Category 1.

Name: Dibenzyl ether
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (RTECS (2006)): "Mildly irritating."

Name: N-Ethylaniline
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A-2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the description of the human health effects (ICSC (J) (2001)): "Redness and pain" (though the severity of the effects are unknown). Although classified into Category 2A-2B, it should be placed in Category 2A from the viewpoint of safety.

Name: 2-chloro-1-phthalimidoethyl O,O-diethyl phosphorodithioate
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: There is the description of slight stimulative in the examination of rabbit (Mild irritation) (JMPR (Joint Meeting on Pesticide Residures - Monographs & Evaluations)363(WHO/IPCS, 1976)), it was classified into Category 2B.

Name: bis(8-quinolinolato)copper
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of irritation which resolved within 7 days, observed in rabbit eye irritation tests using the Draize scheme (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1976)).

Name: dimercury dinitrate
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Due to the description that it may irritate to the eye (HSFS, 1993), it was classified into Category 2B.

Name: 2-Cyclohexylbiphenyl
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: There is the statement that "Temporary eye irritation", but in the case that liquid bounds into the eyes in humans, the extent is unknown (ACGIH (2001), and furthermore that there was no irritation in the rabbit test (ACGIH (2001), IUCLID (2000). So it was classified into Category 2B.

Name: 2-(Diethylamino)ethyl methacrylate
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests: "Severe conjunctival irritation was noted" (though no data are available on reversibility). Classified as Category 1 in accordance with the technical guideline, given the fact that the substance is classified into Category 1A-1C for "2. Skin corrosion/irritation."

Name: Ethyl chloroacetate
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: Due to the descriptions of the result of the experiment to the rabit (Severe (RTECS (1999)) , severe irritation (IUCLID (2000)), "irritation to human eye severely  (ICSC (J) (2001))", "irritation to the eye seriously" (HSDB (2003), SITTIG (4th, 2002), IUCLID (2000)), it was classified into Category 2A.

Name: sec-butyl acetate
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A-2B
Rationale for classification: Vapor and liquid stimulates an eye (HSDB (2005)), and obstacle of the recovery of a grade 5 (the highest grade 10) by the study of the rabbit (HSDB (2005)). So it were set to Category 2A-2B. Since it is unknown about recovery period, subdivide Category cannot be classificationed. (It is more desirable to be set as 2A from a viewpoint of safety, when subdivide Category needs to be performed by display etc.)

Name: epsilon-caprolactam
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (CERI Hazard Data 98-1 (1999)): the substance is considered to cause "moderate irritation."

Name: 2,4-Xylenol
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in ICSC (J) (2003) of the human health effects: "Corrosive to the skin, respiratory tract and eye."

Name: 5-Chloro-N-{2-[4-(2-ethoxyethyl)-2,3-dimethylphenoxy]ethyl}-6-ethylpyrimidine-4-amine; Pylimidifen
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the data from rabbit eye irritation tests that suggest evidence of mild irritation which cleared up after 2-3 days (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1993)).

Name: Sodium dichromate
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: It was set as category 1 based on what the necrosis was looked at by the human conjunctiva, erosion was looked at by the corneal (EU-RAR (2005)), and severe irritation was seen for with the rabbit (IUCLID (2000)).

Name: heptan-3-one
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: We categorized it as Category 2B based on the descriptions that mild irritation was acknowledged by the test applied to the eyes of the rabbits (ACGIH (7th, 2001) and PATTY (4th, 1994)).

Name: p-Xylene
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in CERI Hazard Data 96-30 (iii) (1997): Xylene mixtures (Cas 1330-20-7) cause moderate eye irritation, and the acute effects of p-xylene on human health are considered essentially equivalent to those of xylene mixtures. The substance is considered "moderately irritating" to the eyes.

Name: p-Cresol
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye and skin irritation tests: "Severe irritation to the conjunctiva, cornea and iris is observed, which does not recover within 72 hours" (SIDS (2005)) and "Irreversible damage to the skin is observed" (EHC 168 (1995)).

Name: p-Dichlorobenzene
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests performed in accordance with OECD Guidelines (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.76 (2005)): Redness and edema of the conjunctiva are observed in one out of three specimens, both of which disappear after 72 hours of exposure; mild eye irritation is observed, with no effects on the iris and cornea. The substance is considered "mildly irritating" to the eyes.

Name: p-Chloroaniline
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests performed in accordance with OECD Guidelines (CICAD 48 (2003)): slightly irritating.

Name: p-Toluidine
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on a 1-hour inhalation study in rats (CERI Hazard Data 99-6 (2000)): "The substance produced irritation of the eye and upper respiratory tract." Also based on the evidence of "severe irritation" from a 24-hour eye irritation study in rabbits (CERI Hazard Data 99-6 (2000)). The substance is thus considered severely irritating to the eye.

Name: p-Phenylenediamine
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (CERI Hazard Data 2001-31 (2002)): "The substance induced moderate conjunctivitis, with effects resolving by 24 hours." Also based on the description of human health effects (CERI Hazard Data 2001-31 (2002), MOE Risk Assessment vol. 3 (2004), PATTY (4th, 1999) and DFGOT vol.6 (1994)): "The substance produces severer symptoms in humans including pain and burning sensation in the eyeball followed by erythema and swelling of lid margin along with chemosis and injection of conjunctiva. In some cases, corneal epithelial erosion, iritis and iridocyclitis, while in more serious cases, corneal ulceration are observed, which may develop into visual impairment and blindness."

Name: 7-oxa-3-oxiranylbicyclo[4.1.0]heptane
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2A from description that severe irritation (highly irritating) was accepted in the test applied to the eye of the rabbit of ACGIH (7th, 2001).

Name: Butane, 1,2-epoxy-
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: Based on data (SIDS (2001)) that there is skin corrosivity with a rabbit, it was set as Category 1 according to the technological direction.

Name: Epichlorohydrin
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: Based on the testing data of rabbit eye irritation tests (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.74 (2004)) and data on human health effects (ACGIH (7th, 2001), MOE Risk Assessment Vol. 1 (2002), EHC 33 (1984)), the substance is considered "extremely irritating." Although no data are available on the corrosiveness, the results of rabbit eye irritation tests suggest that 80% epichlorohydrin causes "severe irritation (corneal damage)"; 100% epichlorohydrin may be corrosive.

Name: 2,3-Epoxypropyl methacrylate
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (SIDS (2002)): "The substance produced moderate to severe corneal damage, with no recovery observed over the subsequent 7 days." Also due to the fact that it is classified into Category 1A-1C for skin irritation. The substance is thus considered severely irritating to the eye.

Name: 1-Allyloxy-2,3-epoxypropane
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: Based on the testing data of animal eye irritation tests (CERI Hazard Data 2001-14 (2002), CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.68 (2005), PATTY (4th, 1999)): "severe irritant, with irreversible effects observed."

Name: Ethane, 1,2-dibromo-
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2
Rationale for classification: There is irritation on the conjunctiva and necrotic slight for corneal surfaces by rabbits eye drops, it did not bequeath injury 12 days afterward, and had recovered completely (EHC 177 (1996)). Moreover, it is indicated that there is ocular severe irritation in humans (EHC 177 (1996)). Since it was judged that it had the moderates irritation from these information to an eye, it was set as Category 2.

Name: 1-bromopropane
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2
Rationale for classification: There are descriptions of "Irritation to an eye" as an impact on human in HSDB (2006) and of "An eye is stimulated" in the paragraph of the short-term exposure effects of ICSC (2004). Although the degree is unknown, since it was considered to own irritation, it was classified into Category 2. In addition, EU classification is Xi; R36/37/38 (EU-Annex I).

Name: 3-Bromo-1-propene; Allyl bromide
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on human epidemiological studies (HSDB (2006)): "Causes severe eye burn."

Name: carbendazim(ISO)
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2
Rationale for classification: Since EHC149 (1993) describes as "There is moderate or mild conjunctiva irritation to the eyes of a rabbit from the negative result employing a rabbit and the result of moderate to mild irritation", it is classified into Category 2.

Name: 2',4-Dichloro-alpha,alpha,alpha-trifluoro-4'-nitro-m-toluenesulfonanilide; Flusulfamide
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of severe irritation with effects persisting in one of six test animals after day 7, observed in rabbit eye irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1990)).

Name: Acrolein
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of "irreversible effects on the eye" from the rabbit eye irritation tests (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.66 (2005), EU-RAR No.7 (2001)), and the classification into Category 1 (skin corrosion and irritation).

Name: 3-Chloropropene; Allyl chloride
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on animal eye irritation tests (CERI Hazard Data 98-26 (1999), SIDS (2003)): Mild irritation is observed. And based on the data on human health effects (ACGIH (7th, 2001)): Severe irritation associated with pain and corneal injury is observed, which may cause vision loss. The substance could cause irreversible irritation to the eyes.

Name: 1,2-Dichloroethane
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on human epidemiological studies and rabbit eye irritation tests (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.3 (2004): The results of Draize tests suggest "mild irritation."

Name: 2-Chloroethanol
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: The result which is irritating is obtained in the animal studies (IUCLID (2000)). Although PATTY (5th, 2005) is setting to extremly irritating. But there is no evidence as irreversible, it is set as Category 2A.

Name: allylamine
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A-2B
Rationale for classification:
There is the description of stimulating the human eye (ICSC (J) (1998), SITTIG (4th, 2002), HSDB (2003), or accident exapmles (PATTY (5th, 2001)), it has eye irritation. But it is insufficient of the data which judges subdivision, therefore, it was classified into Category 2A-2B.
[Indication] 2A is recommended based on the safety, when the Category needs to subdivide.

Name: Acrylonitrile
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: Based on the following description by DuPont (1975) on serious eye damage/eye irritation among several testing data in EU-RAR No.32, 2004: "In unwashed eyes, moderate corneal opacity, moderate iritis, severe conjunctival irritation and corneal opacity associated with vascularization observed even after 21 days from exposure. In washed eyes, mild temporary corneal opacity, moderate iris congestion, moderate conjunctival irritation, recovery observed within 3 days from exposure."

Name: Ethylenediamine
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (ACGIH (7th, 2001), CICAD 15 (1999), SIDS (2003): Administration of eye drops (undiluted solution) causes permanent damage to the eyes; the substance is considered to have "irreversible effects" on the eyes.

Name: Allyl alcohol
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on the rabbit eye irritation tests (PATTY (4th, 2000)): "Causes corneal necrosis and severe effects." The substance is thus considered to have "irreversible effects on the eye."

Name: 2-Propyn-1-ol
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: When eyedrops was applied to the rabbit at ACGIH (7th.2001) and PATTY (4th.1994), it was set as Category 1 based on it being indicated that permanent corneal injury takes place.

Name: chloroacetaldehyde
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: This product has skin corrosivity. Based on the statement of the serious damage with rabbit eye (ACGIH (2001)) and ocular tissue damage with human (ACGIH (2001)), and caustic being indicated to an eyeby vapor on this substance (ICSC (J), (1997)). Based on the above statement, it was set to CAtegory 1.

Name: Ethylene glycol
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (CICAD 45 (2002)): Short-term exposure to ethylene glycol (liquid or vapour) causes conjunctival irritation with no permanent damage to the cornea.

Name: Glyoxal
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on the rabbit eye irritation tests: "severe irritant" (CERI Hazard Data 98-8 (1999)); "severe erythema and mild edema of the conjunctiva, and inflammation and opacity of the iris were observed. The reactions resolved 1-2 weeks after exposure"; "severe conjunctival erythema/inflammation and iris inflammation/opacity" (SIDS (2003)). The substance is thus considered to cause severe irreversible irritation of the eye.

Name: Ether, chloromethyl methyl
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: Skin corrosivity / stimulative GHS classification was Category 1, so it categoried into Category 1.

Name: Methyl formate
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A-2B
Rationale for classification: There are statements of stimulative with humans (PATTY (5th, 2001)), and of stimulative in rabbit test (IUCLID (2000)). But there is no resilience data, Category of 2A and 2B is not made. When a display is required, it is recommended of making it 2A from a viewpoint of safety.

Name: 2,4-Pentanediol, 2-methyl-
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: Change of the eye applicable to the standard of irritation was not acknowledged in the eye irritation tests using the rabbits in SIDS (2001) (OECD Guidelines 405 compatible good laboratory practice tests). However, based on the descriptions that severe irritation was acknowledged in the tests applied to the eyes of the rabbits (SIDS (2001), ACGIH (7th, 2001), DFGOT (vol.16, 2001), PATTY (4th, 1994)), and on the description that in the Draize test using the rabbits, change of the eyes did not completely recover within seven days (SIDS (2001)). So we classified it as Category 2A.

Name: TEPP
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A-2B
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2A-2B based on the statement (ACGIH (2001), ICSC (J), (1994), HSDB (2005)) that there were redness, a pain, pupil contraction, a haze eye, lacrimation, and stimulativeness in humans.

Name: Dibutyl phosphate
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: Based on the description that it had severe stimulativeness on the eyes of the rabbits (SIDS (2002)), we classified it as Category 2A.

Name: 2-Pentanone
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A-2B
Rationale for classification: We classified it as Category 2A-2B based on the description that it had mild to moderate stimulativeness in the test applied to the eyes of the rabbits (PATTY (4th, 1994)).

Name: 2-Propanol, 1-methoxy-
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A-2B
Rationale for classification: Severe ocular irritant property was acknowledged at high concentrations in the test which exposed vapors of this product to the volunteers (SIDS (2001), ACGIH (2001), IRIS (2005), PATTY (1994)), but we found no delineation about quickness of examinee's recovery. Therefore we classified it as Category 2A-2B.

Name: Propane, 1-nitro-
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A-2B
Rationale for classification: There is the description that in humans eye irritations were acknowledged by exposure to vapor (ACGIH (7th, 2001), PATTY (4th, 1994), and DFGOT (vol.13, 1999)), and the description that the eyes are stimulated seriously (ICSC (J) and (1996)). So it was set as Category 2A-2B.

Name: Vinyl acetate
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.60 (2004)): "severe irritant."

Name: 2-Pentanol, 4-methyl-
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A-2B
Rationale for classification: We classified it as Category 2A-2B based on the descriptions that the eyes of the rabbits were stimulated moderately (ACGIH (7th, 2001) and PATTY (4th, 1994)). Since there were no descriptions about resilience, deliberate categorization was impossible.

Name: 2-Propanamine, N-(1-methylethyl)-
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 1 based on pH >11.5 (IUCLID (2000)). Moreover, the report with the eye corrosiveness in a rabbit (IUCLID (2000)) also endorses this.

Name: Propane, 2,2'-oxybis-
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A-2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the statement that irritation was acknowledged (IUCLID (2000)) and "minor injury"was produced (HSDB (2003)) in rabbit tests, and based on the statement that irritation was acknowledged in the eye by 800ppm and 5 min in humans, it was set as Category 2A-2B (ACGIH (2001)).

Name: 1-methylethyl acetate
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: There is a statement that stimulativeness of the eye is carried out in humans and it can become a cause of redness or a chemical burn (PATTY and (5th, 2001), ICSC (1998), HSFS (2004), and SITTIG (47th, 2002)), and The Draize method test result in rabbit is "mild reaction" (ACGIH (7th, 2003)). On the other hand, there is a statement that the condition of an eye is recovered for a short times (PATTY (5th, 2001), GESTIS (2005)). It was set as Category 2B based on these information.

Name: Acetic anhydride
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: There is the description that severe irritant property was acknowledged in the tests applied to the eyes of the rabbits (CERI Hazard Data (2001), DFGOT (vol.13, 1999) and SIDS (1997)), and on the description that the drug-induced severe burn injury on the cornea, loss of eyesight, etc. were reported in the occupational exposure examples (CERI Hazard Data (2001), DFGOT (vol.13, 1999), SIDS (1997) and Japan Society for Occupational Health Recommendation of Occupational Exposure Limits (1990)). So we judged it had causticity and classified it as Category 1.

Name: Maleic anhydride
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: Based on the descriptions in the reports on rabbit eye irritation tests : "severe irritation, and occasionally, irreversible damage were observed" (DFGOT vol.4 (1992)); "severe and permanent congestion and corneal vascularization were found" (ACGIH (7th, 2001)).

Name: m-Xylene
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (CERI Hazard Data 96-30 (ii) (1997), CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No. 62 (2004)): The substance causes moderate skin irritation.

Name: m-Cresol
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye and skin irritation tests: "Severe irritation to the conjunctiva, cornea and iris is observed, which does not recover within 72 hours" (SIDS (2005)) and "Irreversible damage to the skin is observed" (EHC 168 (1995)).

Name: m-Chloroaniline
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A-2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in CERI Hazard Data 2000-35 (2001) of eye irritation tests performed in accordance with OECD Test Guideline: "Mild corneal lesion (irreversible) and moderate corneal irritation were observed." Classified as Category 2A-2B, as it is unclear whether the responses resolve by 7 days of observation. The substance should be placed in Category 2A from the viewpoint of safety, if further subclassification is needed.

Name: m-Toluidine
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A-2B
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2A-2B from description that the moderate irritation was admitted by the test using the rabbit of SIDS (2003). Since reparable was unknown, subdivision was not carried out.

Name: m-Phenylenediamine
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A-2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (CERI Hazard Data 98-29 (1999)): "conjunctival injection and corneal opacity were observed." Also based on the description of human health effects (MOE Risk Assessment vol. 3 (2004)): "irritating to the eye." The substance is thus considered an eye irritant (though the severity of the effects is unknown). It should be placed in Category 2A from the viewpoint of safety if further subclassification is needed.

Name: 1,3-Benzenediol
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: We classified it as Category 1 based on the descriptions that it caused the irreversible ulcer on the cornea in the eye irritation tests using the rabbits (ACGIH 7th., 2001, DFGOT 20, 2003).

Name: m-Divinylbenzene
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (RTECS (2006)): "Mildly irritating."

Name: 1,3,5-Trimethylbenzene
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (CERI Hazard Data  2001-51 (2002)): "mildly irritating" (though exposure duration is unknown).

Name: 1,3,5-Trichlorobenzene
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: In DFGOT vol.3 (1992), there is a description of "In the test where 100 mg of this substance was instilled into the eyes of a rabbit, mild and temporary redness, conjunctiva dropsy, and eye discharge arose and the recovery took seven days in the rabbit which was not rinsed." and a description of "The irritation to mucosa ranged from mild to moderate " in the test where it was medicated to the eyes of a rabbit. As mentioned above, it was classified into Category 2B.

Name: 2,4,6-Trichloro-1,3,5-triazine
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: Based on the data on rabbit eye irritation tests (CERI Hazard Data 2000-55 (2001) and (SIDS (2005)) and human health effects (CERI Hazard Data 2000-55 (2001)): "severely irritating." Although classified into Category 1-2A, the substance should be placed in Category 1 from the viewpoint of safety.

Name: 1,3-dimethylbutyl acetate
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the publication that very low eye irritation on the rabbit (PATTY(5th, 2001) vol.6), and that stimulant is in an eye on humans (RTECS (2004), HSDB (2005)), it was set as Category 2B.

Name: Methyl cyclohexane
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in RTECS (2005) that mild irritant property was acknowledged in the test applied to the eyes of the rabbits, and on the descriptions in ICSC (J) (1997) and SITTIG (4th, 2002) that it stimulated the eyes, we categorized it as Category 2B although there were no concrete case reports.

Name: Toluene
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the description that the subjects recovered from the damage within 7 days in rabbit eye irritation test conducted in accordance with the OECD test guideline (EU-RAR No. 30, 2003), which suggests that toluene causes mild eye irritation.

Name: Chlorobenzene
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of "moderate irritation" from rabbit and guinea pig eye irritation tests (ACGIH 7th, 2001) and human reports (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.82, 2005).

Name: Cyclohexylamine
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (CERI Hazard Data 2001-54 (2002)): "Corrosive."

Name: Cyclohexanol
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: Since four in the four animals in the animal tests, the scores of Corneal opacity after 24, 48 or 72 hours are 3 respectively, and in which the one animal has not recovered from the disorder after 21 days (ECETOC TR48 (2), (1998)). So it was set as Category 1.

Name: Cyclohexanone
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: Based on the statement of  "the human eye irritations"(PATTY (5th, 2001) and "the severe irritations in the eye of a rabbit"(CERI Hazard Data (2000), it was set as Category 2A.

Name: Phenol
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: Based on the testing data of rabbit eye irritation tests (EHC 161(1994)): Application of 10% glycerin solution or 5% aqueous solution causes complete corneal opacity, although numerical data are not available. The substance causes irreversible effects on the eye.

Name: Thiophenol
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (CERI Hazard Data 99-2 (2000) and PATTY (4th, 2000)): "Severely irritating, causing conjunctival irritation and corneal lesions," "moderate to severe conjunctival injection, edema and discharge persisted for 3-4 days and healed by day 16 in all affected animals. Corneal opacity progressed on days 16-19, with gradual recovery observed in subsequent 1.5-2 months." The substance is thus considered severely irritating and classified into Category 2A.

Name: 3-Methylpyridine
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: Classified as Category 1 in accordance with the technical guideline, given the fact that the substance is classified into Category 1A-1C for "2. Skin corrosion / irritation."

Name: Ethanol, 2-(1-methylethoxy)-
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2B based on the statement of recovering within seven days although there was irritation (DFGOT vol.V (1993), ECETOC TR4 (1982), PATTY(5th, 2001) vol.7).

Name: Propyl acetate
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2B based on the statement (RTECS (2005)) that the result of Draize tests by rabbits was "mild." (RTECS (2005)) In addition, the irritant against eyes is reported in the exposure tests using a cat (ACGIH (7th, 2001)) and also humans (HSDB (2005)). Moreover, the this product is classified into R 36 by EU.

Name: propyl chloroformate
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: In addition to being skin corrosive substances (Category 1), in Priority 2, there are descriptions which indicates corrosive and severe deep thermal burns to the human eye (ICSC (2005), HSDB (2003), SITTIG (4th, 2002), HSFS (2001)). So it was classified into Category 1.

Name: Pentane
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: In the eye irritation tests with the rabbits, transient conjunctivitis was admitted, however, it recovered within 72 hours (EU-RAR (2003)). So we classfied it as Category 2B also based on the other descriptions.

Name: 1-Butanamine
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: Since Japan Society for Occupational Health Recommendation of Occupational Exposure Limits (1994) and PATTY (4th, 1994) had descriptions which shows that it may cause the critical lesion in the eyes of the rabbits, we classified it as Category 1.

Name: Propiononitrile, 3-hydroxy-
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: As a result of medicating eye of rabbit with this product by standard Draize method, "moderate" irritation is indicated (RTECS(2000)), and the human eye were stimulated (ICSC(J)(2001), and HSDB(2003)). So it was set as Category 2A.

Name: 1-Butanethiol
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: We classified it as Category 2B based on the description that the stimulative reaction continued until after four days at the maximum in the test applied to the eyes of the rabbits (PATTY (4th, 1994)).

Name: Ethylene glycol monomethyl ether
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of mild irritation from rabbit skin irritation tests (PATTY 4th, 2000) and the human evidence of complete recovery within 48 hours (PATTY 4th, 2000), although insufficient data available.

Name: Methane, dimethoxy-
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: We classified it as Category 2A based on the description that the irritant property on the eyes of the guinea pigs was moderate (PATTY (4th, 1994)).

Name: Diethylamine
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: In many animals studies report with irritant (IUCLID (2000)), but there is also a description with damage to a serious eye (ACGIH (2001)). Moreover, since corrosion of the skin / irritation is categoried into Category 1, critical damage / irritation over an eye are set as category 1.

Name: Ethyl formate
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A-2B
Rationale for classification: There are statements of the moderate stimulativeness in the human exposure to vapor (HSDB (2005)), inflammation of a cornea by rabbit test (DFGOTvol.19 (2003)) and moderate stimulativeness (IUCLID (2000)). But there is no resilience data, and Category of 2A and 2B is not made. When a display is required, it is recommended to be set as 2A from a viewpoint of safety.

Name: Tetrahydrofuran
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: Based on the description that there is irritation to the eyes as the effect of the humans (CERI Hazard Data (1999) and ACGIH (7th, 2001)), it was set as Category 2A.

Name: 2-Hexanone, 5-methyl-
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: We classified it as Category 2B based on the descriptions that very slight stimulativeness was acknowledged by application to the eyes of the rabbits (ACGIH (7th, 2001) and PATTY (4th, 1994)).

Name: 2-Methylpropyl acetate
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2B by the test results of Moderate (RTECS (2004)) and slight eye irritation (DFGTO vol.19 (2003)) to the rabbit.

Name: 2-Heptanone
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Change of the eyes which corresponds to the standard of irritation was not admitted in the eye irritation tests using the rabbit (ECETOC TR48 (1992)). However, there is the description that slight irritation was acknowledged in the eyes of the rabbits (PATTY (4th, 1994)). So we classified it as Category 2B

Name: 2-Methoxyethyl acetate; Ethylene glycol monomethyl ether acetate
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (CERI-NITE Hazard Data 2001-69 (2002)): "mild irritation."

Name: Hexane
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A-2B
Rationale for classification: We classified it as Category 2A-2B. Based on the description that the ocular irritant property was acknowledged in human exposure examples (MOE Risk Assessment 1st volume (2002)), and on the description that mild irritant property was acknowledged in the rabbits (DFGOT vol.14 (2000)). The level of irritation and resilience are unknown, therefore deliberate categorization was impossible.

Name: Pentanal
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: We classified it as Category 2A based on the descriptions that it stimulated the eyes of the rabbits seriously (ACGIH (7th, 2001) and PATTY (4th, 1994)).

Name: Ethylene glycol monoethyl ether
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of mild irritation from rabbit eye irritation tests  (ECETOC TR64, 1995)  (PATTY 4th, 2000).

Name: Cyclohexane
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A-2B
Rationale for classification: Since there was a statement that in rabbits corneal cloudings, iritis, conjunctival hyperemias, and chemosis each are seen reversible (EU-RAR (2004), as well as in animals and in humans irritation is in the eye (PATTY (5th, 2001), EU-RAR (2004), ICSC (J), (1994), HSDB (2005)), it was set as Category 2A-2B.

Name: Cyclohexene
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A-2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the statement (ICSC (J), (1999)) that redness is produced in humans, it was set as Category 2A-2B.

Name: Piperazine
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (CERI Hazard Data 2001-13 (2002), CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.19 (2005), PATTY (4th, 2000) and DFGOT vol.9 (1998)): "strong irritation," "severe corneal opacity" and "serious eye damage which is unlikely to heal."  The substance is thus considered to possess a potential for corrosivity.

Name: Pyridine
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on eye irritation tests in rabbits and guinea pigs (CERI Hazard Data 2001-70 (2002), ATSDR (2000), PATTY (4th, 2000) and ACGIH (7th, 2004)): "severe damage," "corneal damage" and "severe injury." The substance is thus considered "corrosive."

Name: Morpholine
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: Based on the description that the edema of membrana mucosa, corneal opacity, and staphyloma were acknowledged when applied to the eyes of the rabbits (EHC 179, 1996), on the description that severe irritation was acknowledged when eyedrop was applied in the solution diluted to 1-40% (EHC 179, 1996, International Agency for Res. on Cancer 47, 1989, PATTY 4th, 1994), and on the description that the solution of this product developed edema to the cornea of the human eyes (International Agency for Res. on Cancer 47, 1989), and on the description that it had severe irritant property (ACGIH 7th, 2001, International Agency for Res. on Cancer 47, 1989, PATTY 4th, 1994). So we classified it as Category 2A

Name: Lasalocid
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2A from description that it stimulates to moderate to the rabbit eye (RTECS, 1986).

Name: Tetrahydromethylphthalic anhydride
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence from rabbit eye irritation tests (SIDS (2005)): The substance induced irritation of the eye. The effects were not fully reversible on day 10.

Name: 2-Ethoxyethyl acetate; Ethylene glycol monoethyl ether acetate
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of "mild irritation" from rabbit eye irritation tests (CERI-NITE Hazard Data 2001-68 (2002)).

Name: Glutaraldehyde
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: In eye irritation test with rabbit, the severe and continuous stimulus accompanied by a necrosis to the conjunctival was acknowledged, and it continued for two weeks with the half of the animals (NICNAS (1994)). Moreover, in another study, corneal opacity got worse three days afterward (NICNAS (1994)). It was set as Category 1 based on these statement. In addition, the example of exposure by the accident which was accepted conjunctiva inflammation, a palpebral edema, heliophobe, etc. by humans is reported (ACGIH (2001)).

Name: N-(2-Aminoethyl)-1,2-ethanediamine; Diethylenetriamine
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: Based on data on human health effects (MOE Risk Assessment Vol. 2 (2003), ACGIH (7th, 2001)) and the testing data of rabbit eye irritation tests (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.50 (2004), SIDS (1996)) ("corrosive," "highly corrosive," and "loss of vision").

Name: 2,2'-Iminodiethanol
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: Severe irritation is indicated by the rabbit (ACGIH (2001), PATTY (5th, 2001)). In humans, there is a statement that redness, a pain, severe burns and caustics are indicated (ICSC (J), (2002)), and it was classified into R41 in EU. So it was set as Category 1.

Name: Ether, bis(2-chloroethyl)-
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: We classified it as Category 2B based on the descriptions that moderate ocular change was acknowledged which recovers within 24 hours in the tests applied to the eyes of the rabbits (ACGIH (7th, 2001) and PATTY (4th, 1994)).

Name: Octane
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A-2B
Rationale for classification: It was segmented into Category 2 from statement of stimulative with an eye(ICSC (1997)). It cannot be classified with 2A or 2B. It is more desirable to be set as Category 2A from safety perspective if subdivision is needed in display etc.

Name: Adiponitrile
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on the rabbit skin irritation tests, "irritating" (SIDS (1998)), "slight irritation" (HSDB (2001)), "slightly irritating" (IUCLID (2000)): "Mild"

Name: Ethanol, 2-butoxy-
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: Severe irritation is acknowledged by multiple studies using the rabbit (SIDS (1997), ECETOCTR48 (1998)). On the other hand, it is described that although corneal opacity is also sometimes caused with a painful irritation in humans, the symptom is generally recovered within several days (DFGOTvol.6 (1986)). It was set as Category 2A based on these information.

Name: Nonane
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A-2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the description that the eyes are stimulated seriously (ICSC (J), (1995), HSDB (2005), HSFS (2000), and SITTIG (4th, 2002)), it was set as Category 2A-2B.

Name: 1-Octanol
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: Based on the score of rabbit eye irritation tests (Jacobs, 1992) (DFGOT vol.20 (2005)): Exposure to undiluted solution causes eye irritation, with the length of recovery period unknown.

Name: bis(2-methoxyethyl)ether
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Although, in FDA guideline studies employing rabbits, the slight irritation is found after 24 hours, the details are unknown (CICAD 41 (2002)). Since ICSC (2004) has described as "It has mild eye irritation," it was classified into Category 2B.

Name: diammonium oxalate
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: Since ICSC(J)(1995), HSFS(1987), and HSDB(2002) had description (pain, and serious burn ) which indicates eye irritation in the human impact, it was set as Category 2A.

Name: Sodium potassium alloys
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: Although there is no data of this product, due to potassium (ID No.1156, CAS No.7440-09-7) and sodium (ID No.1310, CAS No.7440-23-5) having classified into Category 1 in GHS. So this product was also classified into Category 1.

Name: Hexadecan-1-yl(trimethyl)ammonium chloride
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2
Rationale for classification: From the description that, in humans, the steam and the liquid of this substance have eye irritation (HSDB (2003)) and the damages, such as corneal opacity and conjunctiva dropsy are found (GESTIS (Access on October 2008)), it was classified into Category 2.

Name: N,N-Dimethyldodecan-1-ylamine
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: There are descriptions of "moderately irritating" in a rabbit (SIDS (2001)), "severe" irritation in the standard Draize test of a rabbit (RTECS (1997)), and "severe eye irritant" (HSDB (2003)) in humans, and all descriptions are qualitative evaluations. Since it was a skin corrosive substance, it was classified into Category 1.

Name: Decan-1-ol
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2
Rationale for classification: There is a description of "corneal injury is caused" (Patty (5th, 2001)) in the eye irritation test employing rabbits. Moreover, in HSDB (2006), there is a description of "The degree of injury to the eye is level 2 in 10 levels (Level 10 shows the strongest damage.)" in the test employing rabbits. As mentioned above, it was classified into Category 2.

Name: Dodecan-1-ol
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: This substance was set to Category 2B since it showed a "mild irritation (mainly to conjunctiva)" in the eye irritation test employing rabbits for the commercial Laurylalcohol A and B in 68.9% and 63.3% of each of which this substance was contained (SIDS (1992)), and every rabbit recovered in 14 days. In addition, each ingredient of the commercial Laurylalcohol A and B is a higher alcohol, being indicated below. A: C10 accounts for 0.3%, C12 for 68.9%, C14 for 25.1%, C16 for 5.1%, and C18 for 0.3%. Remaining 0.3% is unidentified. B: C10 accounts for 0.1%, C12 for 63.3%, C14 for 24.1%, C16 for 8.3%, and C18 for 0.4%. Remaining 3.8% is unidentified.

Name: 1,2-Oxathiolane 2,2-dioxide
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: As human impact, the concrete case report etc. was not shown. But from description that the eye irritation which stimulates an eye slightly (ICSC (J) (2004)) or that there was slight eye irritation (HSFS (2000), SITTIG (4th, 2002)). So it judged that there was slight eye irritation and was taken as Category 2B.

Name: 2-isopropyloxyphenyl N-methylcarbamate
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2B from description that very slight stimulativeness was acknowledged in the eye of the rabbit of IUCLID (2000).

Name: Bicyclo[2.2.1]hept-5-ene-2,3-dicarboxylic acid, 1,4,5,6,7,7-hexachloro-
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2A from description that severe irritation was admitted in the test applied to the eye of the rabbit in CERI Hazard Data (2002).

Name: 2,2,2-trichloro-1,1-bis(4-chlorophenyl)ethanol
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of irritant effects on the cornea, iris and conjunctiva, which persisted for at least 21 days of observation (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (2005)).

Name: Triphenyl Phosphate
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: We classified it as Category 2B based on the description that a slight conjunctival reddening was acknowledged and it disappeared within 7 days in the test applied to the eyes of the rabbits (DFGOT(vol.2,1991)).

Name: fensulfothion
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2B based on the statement (HSFS (2005)) that irritant to eye might be indicated by contact.

Name: Tris(2-chloroethyl) phosphate
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (CERI Hazard Data 98-22 (1999)): "Mildly irritating."

Name: Tetrafluoroethylene
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in HSDB (2005) of human exposure: "eye contact with the substance causes slight irritation."

Name: Decabromodiphenyl ether
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (EHC 162 (1994), CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.56 (2005)): "Animals treated with the substance showed only transient congestion and edema of the conjunctival membranes. These symptoms subsided by 24 hours," "At 24 hours, only slight redness (4 of 6), only slight edema (2 of 6), and only slight discharge (1 of 6) of the conjunctiva were noted." The substance is thus considered a mild eye irritant.

Name: Bis(2-ethylhexyl) phthalate
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in ACGIH (7th, 2001), ATSDR (2002), EHC 131 (1992) and EU-RAR No.42 (2003): Phthalic acid, bis (2-ethylhecyl) is considered "non-irritating" or "mildly irritating" to the eyes, with the latter adopted for classification.

Name: 2,3,5,6-Tetrachloro-p-benzoquinone
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: Since there were descriptions of "mucosa may be irritated in the section of human influence" (HSDB (2002)), "The corneal necrosis was caused" (HSDB (2002)) in the test where dry powder was applied to the eye of the rabbit, and "Severe irritation and irreversible injury are caused."(BUA 85 (1993)), it was classified into Category 1. EU classification is Xi; R36/38 (EU-Annex I).

Name: 2,4,6-Tribromophenol
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on eye irritation tests (CERI Hazard Data 2001-53 (2002) and CICAD 66 (2005)): "The substance showed moderate irritation."

Name: Benzene, 2-methyl-1,3,5-trinitro-
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2A from description that it had irritant to human eye in CERI Hazard Data(2001).

Name: Benzophenone
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Slight to moderate redness occurred in crystallographic droppings test to eyes of rabbits in the conjunctiva and the nictitating membrane from 1 hour to 24 hours. From the description of "Slight redness was seen in one of three rabbits till 48 hours and all the eyes became normal 14 days after."(Patty (5th, 2001)), it was classified into Category 2B.

Name: N-(4-tert-Butylbenzyl)-4-chloro-3-ethyl-1-methylpyrazole-5-carboxamide; Tebufenpyrad
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of moderate eye irritation (a mean Draize score of about 4) in rabbit eye irritation tests, with effects clearing after 72 hours (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1993)).

Name: 1-({2-[2-chloro-4-(4-chlorophenoxy)phenyl]-4-methyl-1,3-dioxolan-2-yl}methyl)-1H-1,2,4-triazole
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Based on test data from rabbit eye irritation studies (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1992)): "Caused irritation, which resolved within 7 days."

Name: Anthracene
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2
Rationale for classification: "Congestion of a palpebral edema and a conjunctiva" (EU-RAR (2007)) is described about the impact to humans. It has been described that it has "non-irritant" (EU-RAR (2007)) for animals since "In the medication test to the conjunctival sac employing rabbits (US Code of Federal Regulations), there is no influence to cornea and iris, slight to moderate redness of conjunctiva was seen in 4/6 rabbits, and Draize score is 1.0. Moreover, there is also a description of "no cornea damage" (EU-RAR (2007)) in the dropping test to conjunctival sac employing a rabbit. According to Fig. 3.3.1 of the U.N. GHS second edition, it was classified into Category 2 employing the human data described in EU-RAR (2007) which is the information source of List1.

Name: Dimethyl terephthalate
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (exposure duration not presented) (SIDS (2005)): "mildly irritating," "conjunctivitis (recovery period unknown)." Also based on the description of the human health effects (MOE Risk Assessment vol. 3 (2004)): "reddening of the eye." The substance is thus considered a mild irritant.

Name: Benzenamine, 2-methoxy-5methyl-
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: From description that there was severe stimulation in the eye of the rabbit of DFGOT (4 vol. 1992), it was set as Category 2A .

Name: Pyrocatechol
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (ACGIH (7th, 2001)): "rabbits exhibited discharge, moderate conjunctivitis and corneal opacity after exposure. At 72 hours, severe conjunctivitis, iritis and diffuse corneal opacity were found. Conical cornea due to angiogenesis was observed on day 14." Also based on the description in MOE Risk Assessment vol. 2 (2003) of the human health effects: "corrosive to the eye." The substance is thus considered "corrosive."

Name: copper acetoarsenite
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Due to the descriptions that it may irritate to human eye (SITTIG 4th, 2002;HSFS, 1999), and that the dust of this product or arsenic compound shows irritation in human eye with the possibility (HSDB, 2003), it was classified into Category 2B.

Name: copper hexafluorosilicate
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A-2B
Rationale for classification: Although there was no data about this product, fluoride irritaties to the eye in ACGIH-TLV(2005). So it was classified into Category 2A-2B. In addition, it is difficult to subdivide the Category.

Name: Triethylamine
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: There is the description that in the eye irritation tests using the rabbit, caustic was acknowledged (ACGIH (7th, 2001) and DFGOT (vol.13, 1999)). So it was set as Category 1.

Name: Trimethyl phosphite
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2A based on the report of "a reversible serious cornea stimulus and swelling in rabbit test" (ACGIH (2001)).

Name: N,N-Dimethylaniline
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: Since there is the report  of "MODERATE" in the administration test to the eyes of the rabbit, it was set as "Category 2A".

Name: Ammonium chloride
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A-2B
Rationale for classification: There is a statement that stimulates an eye by short-term exposure in humans (ICSC (J), (2000)), and that redness and a pain of the eye are caused as the primary disaster / an acute symptoms (ICSC (J), (2000)). With a rabbit, there are an evaluation with mild (ACGIH (2002), RTECS (2005)) and severe (RTECS (2005)), and a statement that although cataract, iridal bleeding, and the appearance of fibrin of the anterior chamber of eye, etc. were seen, it recovered (HSDB (2005)). It was set as Category 2A-2B based on the above information.

Name: Palygorskite
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: In the case of contacting to a dentistry assistant's eye directly, there is a description that "severe" anterior uveitis and corneal abscess occurred (HSDB (2003)). Since there was no description on resilience, it was classified into Category 2A. In addition, it is suggested that the influence to the eye of this substance is due to the mechanical damage due to the fibrous materials from the description of "this substance exists as a fibrous linear mineral in a clay deposit" (IARC 68 (1997)).

Name: Phosphorus (yellow)
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: A serious injury accompanied by a eyelids convulsion, photophobia and lacrimation by touching the human eye, or corneal cloudings is caused (PATTY (5th, 2001), HSDB (2005)). Or redness, a pain, eyesight loss, and a serious burn are indicated (ICSC (2004)). So it was set as Category 1.

Name: 2-chloro-4,6-bis(ethylamino)-1,3,5-triazine
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of moderate irritation reactions which resolved by 48 hours, observed in rabbit eye irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (2005)).

Name: Diphenylamine
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (IUCLID (2000)): "slightly irritating" and "corrosive." In classification, priority was given to the severer reactions (i.e., "corrosive"), and thus classified into Category 1.

Name: 2,3-Epoxypropyl phenyl ether
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A-2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the description of epidemiological cases (CERI Hazard Data 2000-14 (2001), MOE Risk Assessment vol. 2 (2003), ACGIH (7th, 2002)): The substance is irritating to the eyes, skin and respiratory tract, though its degree is unknown. The substance should be placed in Category 2A from the viewpoint of safety.

Name: dicadmium selenide sulphide
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A-2B
Rationale for classification:
Although there was no data about this product, it irritaties to the eye as selenium compound in ACGIH-TLV(2004). Since there was no data used as the index of subdivision, it was classified into Category 2A-2B.
[Indication] 2A is recommended based on the safety, when the Category needs to subdivide.

Name: Tetraarsenic tetrasulfide
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Although there was no evidence of this product, due to the description that the arsenic compounds particulate irritates to the eye (DFGOT 21, 2005), it was classified into Category 2B.

Name: heptan-4-one
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2
Rationale for classification: Based on the description that in the eye irritation tests in rabits, there is slight irritation (PATTY(5th, 2001) vol.6 p.283, RTECS (2004)), it was set as Category 2.

Name: p-Aminophenol
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (RTECS (2006) and IUCLID (2000)): "Mild," "slightly irritating." The substance is thus considered a mild eye irritant.

Name: Hydroquinone
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 1
Rationale for classification: There are three test examples of the rabbit, guinea pig, and dog which show irritation below mild. However, there is one test example of the rabbit which shows corrosiveness and the test description of the example is reliable. Therefore, it will be appropriate to modify "Category 2A-2B"to "Category 1" in three-ministry GHS classification. In addition, the EU risk aphorism is also equivalent to "Category 1."

Name: N-methylformamide
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Based on the statement of the "eye irritation" of ICSC (2001) and HSDB (2002), and the statement of HSDB (2002) of  "the onset of conjunctivitis is indicated and the effect is mild in animals studies," it is classified into Category 2B. In addition, GESTIS (Access on Feb.2008) of Priority 3 indicates as "Since the test result to eyes of rabbits varies, it is necessary to take into consideration the reversible damage at the time of contacting human's eyes directly".

Name: Diacetone alcohol
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2A using information of moderate or highly irritating with a rabbit (SIDS (2000), PATTY (5th, 2001)), and that there is irritation with humans (SIDS (2000),  ACGIH (2001)).

Name: 3-Methylbutan-1-ol
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A
Rationale for classification: Since the strong stimulus was given to the eye of a rabbit (ACGIH (2001)), it was set as "Category 2A."

Name: Butyl acetate
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2B
Rationale for classification: Corneal opacity recovery on the second day, iris was not seeing impact, and redness of the conjunctive had recovered on the 7th day and 14th day. So it was taken as Category 2B.

Name: 1,4-Dioxane
Classification: Serious eye damage / eye irritation - Category 2A-2B
Rationale for classification: The data about human health effects showed clear positive reactions (CERI Hazard Data Book (1998), CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment Report (2004) and RU-RAR No.21 (2002)).
